<neobliviscar@...> wrote:
>
> bh325,
> 
> You have done a good job=
 describing it, though a
> picture tells alot. If it is not possible or pra=
ctical
> to take a picture, you might consider taking it to a
> sword club =
near you.
> 
> Given the size and curvature of the blade, it is
> probably =
a wakizashi or a naginata-naoshi (a halberd
> like weapon that has been cut=
 down to make an oversize
> tanto. "O-tanto" basically is a large or oversi=
zed
> tanto). The mounts sound fine to me. Many of these
> came back as sou=
evinirs with WW2 veterans. As they
> played with them over the years, parts=
 <handles,
> seppas, etc> got mixed and matched.
> 
> Don't mess with the b=
lade using any cleaning
> chemicals. Despite the polish being gone and the =
edge
> destroyed, there may be some life left to it.
> 
> Please share in w=
hat state or country you live, and we
> will try to point you to a nearby s=
word society or
> club.
> 
> Curran
